etymology.description: Originally 艸(艸) (cǎo, "grass") + 犬(犬) (quǎn, "dog") = dog in grass barking playfully -> Later 竹(竹) (zhú, "bamboo") + phonetic 夭(夭) (yāo) = sound of laughing or smiling
etymology.interpretation: The character originally combined elements of a dog interacting with grass, perhaps evoking playful barking, which was phonetically associated with laughter. The later addition of 竹 emphasized the written form, while 夭 served as the phonetic component.

examples.chinese: 他笑着(他笑著)，走上舞台(走上舞臺)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiào zhe, zǒu shàng wǔtái.
examples.english: He walked onto the stage while laughing.

examples.chinese: 她笑着说(她笑著說)，‘别笑了’(‘別笑了’)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiào zhe shuō, 'bié xiào le'.
examples.english: She laughed as she said, 'Stop laughing.'

examples.chinese: 我喜欢笑(我喜歡笑)，大笑能缓解压力(大笑能緩解壓力)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xǐhuan xiào, dà xiào néng huǎnjiě yālì.
examples.english: I love to smile, and laughing heartily can relieve stress.
